[Treatise] Question:
Among the four establishments of mindfulness, there are various contemplations. Why only speak of twelve kinds of contemplation - namely, internal, external, and internal and external?
Moreover, what are the internal?
What are the external?
Having contemplated internally and externally, why then separately speak of internal and external?
Moreover, among the four establishments of mindfulness, one establishment of mindfulness is internal, included within internal dharmas, namely the mind;
two establishments of mindfulness are external, included within external dharmas, namely feeling and dharmas;
one establishment of mindfulness is internal and external, included within internal and external dharmas, namely the body.
Why speak of the four dharmas as all being internal, all being external, and all being internal and external?
Why not just say contemplating the body but say attentively contemplating the body?
How does one contemplate the body without giving rise to the perception of a body?
Why speak of diligent, single-minded?
Why is it said that all thirty-seven factors of enlightenment should be practiced single-mindedly, yet only here is it said single-minded?
When practicing the four establishments of mindfulness, all five hindrances should be eliminated. Why is it said to eliminate only greed?
Worldly joy can also hinder the path. Why is it said to eliminate only sorrow?
The Dharma of contemplating the body has various approaches:
impermanence, suffering, emptiness, no-self, etc. Why is it said here only to contemplate impurity?
If one only contemplates impurity, why is it also said to contemplate the four deportments of the body, etc.?
This is easy to understand, so why ask about it?
Answer:
These twelve kinds of contemplation are what the practitioner attains concentration from.
Previously there were three kinds of wrong practices, whether internal, external, or both internal and external;
These three kinds of wrong practices are destroyed, therefore there are three kinds of right practices.
Some people are more attached to internal things and less attached to external things;
It is like a person who, for the sake of his body, can abandon wife, children, relatives, and treasures.
Some people are more attached to external things and less attached to internal things;
It is like a person who covets wealth and loses his life, or who drowns for the sake of desire.
Some people are more attached to both internal and external things - for this reason, three kinds of right practices are taught.
Furthermore, one's own body is called the internal body, and the bodies of others are called the external body;
The nine receptive faculties are called the internal body, and the nine unreceptive faculties are called the external body;
The five faculties such as the eyes are called the internal body, and the five sense objects such as form are called the external body;
Such distinctions are made between internal and external.
The practitioner first contemplates the internal body with the wisdom of impurity, impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self, and does not find any good characteristics in this body:
Whether it be the characteristic of purity, the characteristic of permanence, happiness, self, or reality.
Having not found it internally, he further contemplates the external body, seeking purity, permanence, self, happiness, and reality, but they cannot be found either.
If one cannot attain it, doubts arise:ğŸ”½When observing internally, I may mistake externally;
when observing externally, I may mistake internally.
Now observing internally and externally simultaneously, it is also unobtainable.

At this time, the mind attains right concentration, knowing that this body is impure, impermanent, suffering, empty, and without self, like a disease, like a boil, like a wound, with the nine orifices flowing with filth, this is like a latrine;
it will soon break down, disperse, perish, and die;
it is always surrounded by the sufferings of hunger, thirst, cold, heat, whipping, binding, scolding, reviling, old age, and disease, and is not free.

Internally empty, without an owner, also without a knower, seer, doer, or experiencer, but only with the combination of empty dharmas and causes and conditions, self-arising and self-ceasing, without any affiliation, just like grass and trees, therefore internally and externally are observed together.
The meanings of the other internal and external [aggregates] are explained in the Eighteen Emptinesses.
Contemplating the body means to investigate and observe, knowing it to be impure, decaying, old, sick, and dead, rotting and stinking, with bones and joints decaying and returning to the earth.
Like this body of mine, covered with thin skin, causing people to be deluded, with myriad worries and fears.
For this reason, as the body's characteristics follow internally and externally, one observes from beginning to end.
Moreover, it is as the Buddha explained the method of contemplating the body.
Not giving rise to bodily perceptions means not grasping the body's characteristics of sameness or difference to give rise to discursive thoughts.
Sentient beings give rise to various perceptions within this body:
Some give rise to pure perceptions, some give rise to impure perceptions;
Some give rise to perceptions of anger, thinking of others' faults;
Some people contemplate this body:
What kind of dharma is the body?
Are the various parts of the body the same or different?
They do not give rise to such various perceptions.
Why is it so?
Because it is of no benefit and obstructs the path to nirvana.

Furthermore, other ordinary beings and Å›rÄvakas can contemplate the body by grasping the characteristics of the body, but bodhisattvas can contemplate the body without grasping the characteristics of the body.

Diligent, single-minded means that other worldly skills have been constantly practiced and done since beginningless time, like it is easy to part from strangers but difficult to part from acquaintances;
it is easy to part from acquaintances but difficult to part from parents;
it is easy to part from parents but difficult to part from one's own body;
it is easy to part from one's own body but difficult to part from the mind.
Without being single-minded and diligent, this cannot be attained!
It is like rubbing sticks to seek fire - only by being single-minded, diligent, and not resting can one obtain fire. Therefore, it is said single-mindedly diligent.
Eliminating worldly greed and sorrow means that when greed is eliminated, the five hindrances are all gone;
It is like breaking bamboo - once the first joint is broken, the rest will all go.

Furthermore, the practitioner, having renounced the five desires and gone forth to study the path, having already abandoned worldly pleasures but not yet attained the bliss of concentration, may sometimes give rise to thoughts of worry, like a fish that delights in water.
The nature of the mind is like this, always seeking pleasant things, and thinking back to the desires of the past.
The practitioner often gives rise to these two kinds of thoughts, and therefore the Buddha says to eliminate greed and worry.
Speaking of greed is the same as speaking of worldly joy, because they are mutually related.

As for contemplating impurity first, the human body is impure, but because it is covered by a thin skin, one first gives rise to the notion of purity, and later gives rise to the other inverted views;
For this reason, the contemplation of impurity is explained first.
Furthermore, sentient beings are mostly attached to desire and grasp at the notion of purity;
Hatred and wrong views are not like this, and therefore greed and desire are treated first by contemplating impurity.
As for contemplating the four deportments of the body and so forth, one first wishes to destroy the thief of the body;
A person who attains single-mindedness can accomplish all that they set out to do.

Therefore, first contemplate the body's actions, movements, coming and going, lying down, waking up, sitting in meditation, and what the body does, always with a single-minded calmness, without error or confusion.
Contemplate in this way, and the samÄdhi of impurity will be easily attained.
Although the body may be calm, various evil thoughts and contemplations within can destroy and disturb the mind;
Therefore, the sixteen aspects of counting the breath are taught to prevent thoughts and contemplations.
The meaning of counting the breath has been explained before.
When the body is calm and the mind is not confused, then practice the contemplation of impurity, which is peaceful and firm.
If one first practices the contemplation of impurity, because the mind is crazy and confused, impurity may be transformed into the appearance of purity.
In the Buddha's teachings, these two methods are called the initial gateway to immortality.
The contemplation of impurity means that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate the body as no different from grass, trees, tiles, or stones.
The four external elements transform into food and drink, nourishing the body:
The solid is earth, the moist is water, the hot is fire, and the moving is wind;
These four enter the body and become the body.
Among these four parts, each lacks a self and nothing belonging to a self. They follow their own characteristics and do not follow the mind's intentions.
Suffering, emptiness, etc. are also explained in the same way.
Whether sitting or standing means that lying down leads to laziness because the body does not move, and the mind also does not move;
Walking causes the mind to be distracted because the body is not still, and the mind also is not still.
Desiring to use the eyes to see things, let alone what is not seen, therefore a metaphor is given:

The ox is the practitioner's body, the butcher is the practitioner, the knife is sharp wisdom, taking the ox's life is breaking the body's single characteristic, and the four parts are the four elements.
A butcher observes a cow's four parts, there is no other cow, and it is also not a cow;
The practitioner observes the body's four elements in the same way.
These four elements are not called the body.
Why is it so?
This is because the four are one with the body;
Moreover, the four elements are the general characteristics, while the body is the specific characteristics;
If the external four elements are not called the body, entering the body is provisionally called the body.
I am not in the four elements, and the four elements are not in me;
I am far from the four elements, but due to inverted and false conceptualization, I take them to be the body.
Using this wisdom of emptiness of dispersion, I distinguish the four elements and derivative form, and then enter the three foundations of mindfulness, thus entering the path.
Moreover, this body, from the feet to the hair, from the hair to the feet, is surrounded by thin skin;
Repeatedly contemplating, there is not a single pure place.
Hair, body hair, and so forth, in brief there are thirty-six, in detail there are many.
The granary is the body, the farmer is the practitioner, and the field and seeds are the causes and conditions of the practitioner's bodily actions.
The ripening of the grain entering the granary is the practitioner's causes and conditions ripening and obtaining a body.
Rice, hemp, millet, and other grains are the various impurities in the body.

When the farmer opens the granary, he immediately knows the various differences between hemp, millet, wheat, beans, etc. This is the practitioner's contemplation of impurity. With the eye of wisdom, he sees this body granary and knows that this body is filled with impurity, will surely decay, whether harmed by others or dying on its own.
In this body, there is only feces, urine, impurity, various kinds of foul discharge, etc.
Having contemplated the impurity of one's own body, one now contemplates the decay of the external body;
Therefore, two kinds of impurity are spoken of:
First, that which has decayed, second, that which has not yet decayed.
First, contemplate one's own body that has not yet decayed and has consciousness. If one has thin afflictions and sharp faculties, one will immediately give rise to disgust;
For those with dull faculties and thick afflictions, they contemplate a dead body that has already decayed, which is frightening and disgusting.
Even if it has been dead for one to five days, relatives still guard it;

at this time, birds and beasts have not yet eaten it, and it turns blue and swollen, with pus and blood flowing out, the belly bloated and bursting, the five viscera rotten and decaying, with feces and urine stinking, extremely disgusting and loathsome.
The practitioner thinks:
This form was previously beautiful, with seductive gestures and mannerisms, confusing people's emotions, and those with lust loved and clung to it;
now, upon observing it, where is the beauty?
As the Buddha said, it is truly an illusory dharma, only deceiving the eyes of the ignorant!
Now, this real thing is revealed, and the practitioner immediately thinks:
My body and that are no different;
I have yet to escape this dharma, so how can I be attached to myself and others?
Moreover, why do I value myself and belittle others?
Having contemplated in this way, the mind becomes subdued, and one can seek the Way and eliminate worldly greed and worry.
Moreover, one further contemplates:
When this corpse first dies, birds and beasts see it and think it is not a dead person, and dare not come near.
For this reason, it is said that after six or seven days, when relatives have left, crows, vultures, and jackals will compete to come and eat it.
When the skin and flesh are exhausted, changing day by day, for this reason it is said that there is only a skeleton.
Seeing it like this, one further gives rise to a mind of disgust and thinks:
This heart, liver, skin, and flesh truly have no self. It is only due to this body that the causes and conditions of sin and blessings are accumulated, and immeasurable suffering is experienced!
One then further thinks to oneself:
My body will not last long, and will surely be like this, not yet free from this dharma.
Sometimes the practitioner sees a skeleton on the ground, drenched by rain and water, sun-exposed and wind-blown, with only white bones left;
Or seeing bones for a long time, the tendons and joints severed and scattered in different places, the color like a dove;
Or rotten and decayed, the same color as the earth.
First contemplating the thirty-six substances, a bloated corpse, from one day to five days, is the contemplation of impurity.
Birds and beasts come to eat, until the same color as the earth, this is the contemplation of impermanence.

In this, the self and what belongs to the self cannot be obtained, as explained before, because of being born from causes and conditions and not being independent, this is the contemplation of non-self.
Contemplating the body's characteristics like this, there is nothing enjoyable;
If there is attachment, then sorrow and suffering arise, this is called the contemplation of suffering.
Contemplating the external body with the four noble practices, knowing for oneself that one's own body is also like this, then externally and internally together contemplating.
If the mind is scattered, one should think of old age, sickness, death, the suffering of the three evil paths, the impermanence of life and body, and the Buddha's teachings about to disappear;
In this way, whip the mind to subdue it and return it to the contemplation of impurity. This is called diligent effort.
Because of single-minded diligent effort, one can eliminate greed and worry.
Greed and worry, these two thieves, rob me of the Dharma treasures. The practitioner thinks like this:
This body is impermanent, impure, and despicable;
Why do sentient beings, for this body, give rise to various causes and conditions of offenses?
Having contemplated in this way, he knows that within this body there are five senses, and outside there are five desires. Because of their combination, the upside-down happiness of the world arises!
The human mind seeks happiness, but there is never a time of abiding.
One should contemplate whether this happiness is real or false?
The body is solid, yet it will still disintegrate, let alone this happiness!
This happiness also has no place to abide. In the future it does not yet exist, in the past it has already ceased, and in the present it does not abide, with each thought moment all ceasing;
Because it obstructs suffering, it is called happiness, but there is no real happiness!

It is like food and drink, which temporarily bring pleasure by relieving hunger and thirst, but when overindulged, they give rise to suffering again, as explained earlier in the refutation of pleasure.
One should know that worldly pleasures all arise from causes of suffering and can also give rise to suffering as a result;
They deceive people for a moment, but later the suffering is immeasurable.
It is like delicious food mixed with poison. Although the food is fragrant and delicious, the poison will harm people;
Worldly pleasures are also like this.
Because of the poison of afflictions such as sexual desire, they rob the life of wisdom, and the mind becomes deluded, abandoning benefits and taking on misfortune. Who experiences this pleasure?
There is only the mind and consciousness.
Contemplate this mind, moment by moment arising and ceasing, yet continuing in a series, so one can grasp its characteristics;
It is like water waves and candle flames.

The mind experiencing suffering is not the mind experiencing pleasure, the mind experiencing pleasure is not the mind experiencing suffering, the mind experiencing neither suffering nor pleasure is not the mind experiencing suffering or pleasure. The characteristics of each moment are different. Therefore, the mind is impermanent.
Because of impermanence, [things] are not self-sovereign. Because of not being self-sovereign, [they] are without self.
Thinking, intention, recollection, and so forth are also like this.
The internal and external characteristics of the other three foundations of mindfulness are as explained above.
These four are the four noble practices, which break through the four inverted views;
Because of breaking through the four inverted views, the gate to the true nature is opened;
Having opened the gate to the true nature, one is ashamed of one's past habits.
It is like a person who eats impure food at night. Others know it is wrong and are ashamed of it.
Contemplating these four dharmas as impure, impermanent, and so forth is called the truth of suffering;
The causes of suffering, such as craving and other afflictions, are the truth of the accumulation [of suffering];ğŸ”½The cessation of craving and other afflictions is the truth of cessation;
The means to eliminate craving and other afflictions is the truth of the path.
Contemplating the four truths in this way, one has faith in the path to nirvana, and the mind abides in bliss, resembling the uncontaminated. This is called the dharma of warmth.
It is like a person rubbing sticks to start a fire, there is definitely warmth, and they expect to obtain fire.
Having faith in this Dharma, one's mind delights in the Buddha. This Dharma is as the Buddha has said, like taking good medicine to cure illness, knowing the teacher to be wonderful;
Those who take the medicine and cure their illnesses are the best among people. This is faith in the Saá¹…gha - such is faith in the Three Jewels.
As the heat-like Dharma progresses, sin and blessings stop and become equal, so it is called the peak Dharma.
It is like a person climbing a mountain to the peak, with the paths on both sides being the same distance.
From the peak to acceptance, up to arhatship, is one path;
From heat to peak is another path.
In the ÅšrÄvaka Dharma, contemplating the four establishments of mindfulness, the rewards obtained are like this.

In the Bodhisattva Dharma, within this contemplation, one does not forget one's original vow, does not abandon great compassion, first using the emptiness of non-attainment to subdue the mind-ground, abiding in this ground, although there are afflictions, the mind always does not fall;
It is like a person who has not yet killed the thief, but is bound in one place.
The bodhisattva's peak practices are as explained in the chapter on the stages of the Dharma.
The practices of forbearance and the supreme worldly dharmas are the bodhisattva's acquiescence to the Dharma of suffering.
The path of the stream-enterer, up to the path of the arhat and pratyekabuddha, is the bodhisattva's acquiescence to the Dharma of non-production.
As the Buddha himself explains in a later chapter:
The wisdom and fruits of the stream-enterer are all the bodhisattva's acquiescence to the Dharma of non-production.
Although the four right efforts and the four bases of supernatural power each have different stages, they are all within the four establishments of mindfulness.
Because wisdom is predominant, it is called the four establishments of mindfulness;ğŸ”½because effort is predominant, it is called the four right efforts;
because concentration is predominant, it is called the four bases of supernatural power.
Question:
If that is so, then why not speak of the stage of wisdom but speak of the stage of mindfulness?
Answer:
When first practicing, one has not yet attained wisdom;
Mindfulness is the initial gateway. Constantly mindful of its matters, it is wisdom following mindfulness, thus it is named mindfulness.
The actual substance of the four establishments of mindfulness is wisdom.
Why is it so?
Contemplating the internal and external body is precisely wisdom;
Mindfully upholding wisdom within the object, not allowing it to be scattered, is called establishment of mindfulness.
It is contrary to the ninety-six kinds of deviant practices seeking the Way, thus it is called right effort.
The non-Buddhists abandon the five desires and torment their bodies, yet they cannot abandon evil and unwholesomeness, and they cannot accumulate wholesome dharmas.
The Buddha has two kinds of methods for eliminating evil and unwholesomeness:
Removing what has already come, and preventing what has not yet come from arising;
Wholesome dharmas also have two kinds:
Causing wholesome dharmas that have not yet arisen to arise, and causing wholesome dharmas that have already arisen to increase and flourish. This is called right effort.
The fire of wisdom, when aided by the wind of right effort, there is nothing it does not burn.
If right effort exceeds, the mind becomes scattered and the fire of wisdom is weak;
Just as fire, when too windy, may be extinguished or weak, and cannot burn or illuminate.
Therefore, one needs concentration to restrain excessive vigor, and then one can attain concentration.
There are four kinds of concentration:
Concentration of desire, concentration of vigor, concentration of mind, and concentration of contemplation.
Restraining excessive wisdom in the four foundations of mindfulness, at this time the path of concentration and wisdom obtains vigor, and one's desires are as one wishes;
Later, obtaining the accomplishment of one's desires is called the bases of spiritual power.
Bases are called the conditions for spiritual powers, and are also called factors.
These twelve dharmas, among those with dull faculties, are called faculties, like a tree with faculties that are not yet powerful;
If among those with sharp faculties, they are called powers, because this matter is clear and can quickly accomplish things, like a sharp knife cutting objects, it is called having power.
Because the matter is not yet accomplished, it is called the path;
Having accomplished the task, contemplating and practicing is called enlightenment.
The discussion of the thirty-seven factors is as explained above.
Question:
If bodhisattvas cultivate these thirty-seven factors, why do they not attain nirvana?
Answer:

Because their original vows are firm, because their great compassion is deeply rooted, because they clearly understand the true nature of all dharmas, and because they are protected and remembered by the buddhas of the ten directions.
As the sutra says:
When bodhisattvas reach the seventh stage, they externally contemplate the emptiness of all dharmas and internally contemplate the absence of self.

The sun, moon, and years - a day is named from dawn to dawn, with the first, middle, and last parts;
the night also has three parts.
A day and night has thirty periods:
In the spring and autumn equinoxes, fifteen periods belong to the day, fifteen periods belong to the night;
The remaining periods increase and decrease - in the fifth month, there are eighteen periods of daytime and twelve periods of nighttime;
In the eleventh month, there are eighteen periods of nighttime and twelve periods of daytime.
A month is either thirty days, or thirty and a half days, or twenty-nine days, or twenty-seven and a half days.
There are four kinds of months:
First, the solar month, second, the worldly month, third, the lunar month, fourth, the lunar mansion month.
The solar month is half a month of thirty days;
The worldly month is thirty days;
The lunar month is twenty-nine days plus sixty-two thirty-seconds;
The lunar mansion month is twenty-seven days plus sixty-seven twenty-firsts.
The intercalary month comes from the solar month and the worldly month, which is called the thirteenth month.
Either twelve months or thirteen months is called a year.
This year has three hundred and sixty-six days, and then it starts over again.

The Bodhisattva knows that at noon, the previous part has already passed, the later part has not yet arisen, and in the middle part there is no place to dwell, no characteristics to grasp, and the part of the day is empty and nonexistent.
When it reaches the thirtieth day, the twenty-ninth day has already ceased. How do they combine to form a month?
If there is no month, how can they combine to form a year?
For this reason, the Buddha said:
The dharmas of the world are like illusions and dreams, they only deceive the mind.
The bodhisattva is able to know that the combination of worldly days, months, and years can be analyzed and found to be non-existent, this is called skillful discrimination.
